Command Line Syntax

May 3, 2021

What is the Command Line?

A command-line interface (CLI) is a user interface that’s navigated by typing commands at prompts, instead of using a mouse.

Basic Syntax

  • echo hello
  • ctrl-c cancels command, as well as esc
  • man echo → manual that has a list of available commands, in this case it defines echo
  • man man → manual prints out definition of man
  • \n → means newline, puts the string on to a new line
  • ctrl-a → moves cursor to the beginning of the line
  • ctrl-e → moves cursor to the end of the line
  • ctrl-u → clears to the beginning of the line (delete and start over)
  • some systems you can use option-click to go to a specific point on the line
  • clear or ctrl-l → clears the screen
  • exit or ctrl-d → exits the program
  • “hello world” > file.txt → prints string into file
  • cat → prints the contents of the file on to the screen
  • “hello world” > file.txt → adds the line to the end of the file
  • diff file1.txt file2.txt → shows the differences between two files
  • ls → lists files and directories
  • touch file → creates an empty file with name file
  • cd → change directories, use cd .. to go up a directory
  • ls *.txt → lists all files ending in .txt
  • ls -l → lists date and time the file was modified
  • ls -rtl → reversed time of modification (most recently modified appear at bottom of screen)
  • .file → hides file
  • mv test file.txt → renames file.txt into test_file.txt
  • cp file1.txt file2.txt –> copies files
  • rm → removes files
  • tab key when typing out long file name auto completes it
  • double tab to see all possibilities
  • rm -f → overrides confirmation, force deletes all files specified
